Graphical abstract Due to its high energy and pollution-free emission, ammonia has a bright future as an energy and hydrogen carrier. The mechanism studies and catalysts design of AOR provide infinite possibility for energy release of ammonia. Green and sustainable options are needed to ease the current energy and environmental crisis, and alleviate the greenhouse effect and energy shortage. As an alternative carbon–neutral synthetic fuel, ammonia shows great potential due to its high energy density, non-toxic by-products, and mature related infrastructures. However, related practical applications have been severely hampered on ammonia-oxidation due to the high cost of catalysts and immature energy utilization systems. Here, we comprehensively summarized the efforts which have been made in recent years with the aim of providing a deep sight into the development and deficiencies in this territory and trying to establish a simple framework of basic knowledge for researchers. The exploration of mechanism is discussed first and then the relevant catalysts studied in recent years are summarized. Besides, the progress of direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs) is also presented and the challenges as well as perspectives on future developments of electrocatalysts for ammonia electro-oxidation and its practical application are provided at the end. Keywords Ammonia Ammonia electro-oxidation reaction (AOR) Mechanism Electrocatalysts DAFCs 1 Introduction Petroleum fossil resources are the main energy sources in the world at present, suffering from the unrecoverable recovery and limited total amount, leading to tight energy supply and rising prices [1–4]. The energy supply crisis has strongly pushed the whole human society to seek greener, safer, more sustainable, and efficient energy systems such as solar, electrical, wind, and nuclear power systems [5]. Among the secondary energy carriers, hydrogen is undoubtedly one of the optimal economic and environmental carriers due to its abundance, ubiquity, zero carbon emission, and high energy density, etc. [6]. However, incompatibility between current petroleum-based infrastructures and hydrogen storage along with utilization systems makes the cost of energy replacement impressively huge [7]. On the other hand, gaseous hydrogen in an ambient condition brings great difficulties and safety issues to the transportation and storage of hydrogen [8–10]. To ease the awkward situation of hydrogen utilization, finding a suitable hydrogen carrier has become an important method to solve the transportation and storage issues (Table 1 ). As for the main source of hydrogen at present, methane reforming is the most practical choice at present [11,12]. The source of methane is extensive, and the scale of the industry is perfect, resulting in lower cost and wide application [13]. However, steam reforming and thermocatalytic decomposition of methane are the most commonly used methods for industrial hydrogen production suffering from the disadvantages of CO x release and high energy input, respectively [14]. And the transportation and storage issues still remain for methane due to the similar physical properties to hydrogen. In addition, electrooxidation of relevant carriers (such as hydrogen and ammonia) is a powerful way to utilize the energy while methane is electrochemical inertness at room temperature due to the stable structure (symmetrical tetrahedral configuration) and extremely strong C–H bond (425 kJ mol−1) of methane [15,16]. Other hydrogen carriers, such as liquid organic hydrogen carriers, are limited by the slow hydrogen release rate, poor recycle ability, and expensive cost [17,18]. In this regard, ammonia is considered as an alternative energy source and carrier for hydrogen [19–21]. Unlike hydrogen, ammonia is widely used in the world, involving fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, and chemical industries, making its related infrastructure consummate [22] (an annual global production of 176 million metric tons [2]). Therefor, the source of the feedstock benefits from the mature related infrastructure of ammonia production, and green and sustainable ammonia synthesis technologies (biosynthesis, photocatalysis, electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, etc) are also in the stage of rapid development [2]. Furthermore, it is easily liquefied at room temperature (≈8 bar), reducing transportation and storage costs and dangers. As for stability, ammonia (Δf H o 298 K = 46 kJ mol−1) is neither as stable as H2O (Δf H o 298 K = 286 kJ mol−1) nor as unstable as hydrogen [19,23]. And what is interesting is that once the content in the atmosphere reaches 1 ppm, human's sense of smell can detect the presence of ammonia, making the problem of ammonia leakage and spill liable to address and prevent [23]. All these characteristics indicate the potential and prospect of ammonia replacing hydrogen. Apart from the stability and cost, the power density is also the key to evaluate energy reliability. The raw energy density of liquid ammonia is 11.5 MJ kg−1 which is higher than the 8.5 MJ kg−1 for liquid hydrogen and 4.5 MJ kg−1 for compressed hydrogen at 690 bar and 15 °C. It has a high hydrogen content (17.7 wt%) and volumetric energy density (10.5 MJ L−1), more two times higher than that of compressed hydrogen at 700 bar (5.0 MJ L−1) [28]. Electrocatalytic ammonia oxidation reaction (AOR) is a promising manner to not only provide hydrogen but also directly generate electricity [20,23]. AOR provides the opportunity to build a more energy efficient system than water splitting as only 33 MJ of energy is needed to generate 1 kg hydrogen, while 180 MJ is required in the latter case [41]. Aside from hydrogen carrier, the use of ammonia for direct fuel cell has also been beneficial from many standpoints. It is a cost-effective option with less energy consumption compared to conventional hydrogen fuel cell for low production, transportation, and storage costs of ammonia [8]. Towards environmental friendliness, direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs) exhaust completely harmless and inert gas nitrogen, free of CO x released by direct methanol or ethanol fuel cells. Moreover, DAFCs could theoretically provide more energy than hydrogen both in terms of power density and open circuit voltage [42]. When paring with ongoing researches on corresponding devices of fuel cell and catalysts, DAFCs hold strong potential to solve future energy crisis. However, despite the problems of the greenhouse effect have been alleviated, ammonia itself also brings environmental problems. Residual ammonia in industrial wastewater and agricultural fertilizers causes environmental problems such as promotion of eutrophication, emission of offensive stench and potential carcinogenesis [43–45]. Removal of the residual ammonia is the integral part of the severe world environmental problems. At present, well-developed methods for removing ammonia include bacterial degradation, physical membrane separation, chemical decomposition, and advanced oxidation methods [2,46]. While have been applied for a lot of years, these methods suffered from their instinct drawbacks such as high expenditure, low efficiency or poisonous chemical remains. AOR have become the powerful mean of removing ammonia due to its simple equipment and no residue. In our work, we comprehensively summarized the efforts which have been made on AOR in recent years, with the aim of providing a deep sight into the development and deficiencies in this respect and trying to establish a simple framework of basic knowledge for researchers. The exploration of mechanisms was discussed first including Oswin-Salomon mechanism and Maurer-Gerischer mechanism, and the corresponding in situ techniques used in the revealing the essence are also represented. And then we summarized the relevant catalysts, mainly focusing on the Pt-based and Ni-based catalysts along with other mentioned electrodes such as boron-doped diamond. Besides, the progress of DAFCs was also presented with the development involving potassium hydroxide electrolytes, molten hydroxide electrolytes, high temperature solid oxide fuel cells, and low temperature alkaline membrane fuel cells. Finally, the challenges and perspectives on future developments of electrocatalysts for ammonia electro-oxidation and its practical applications were provided in the end, including mechanism, catalysts, alkaline membranes, and corresponding fuel cells. 2 Mechanism and characterization methods 2.1 Overview of AOR mechanism The researches on the mechanism of ammonia oxidation have gone through decades, but its essence is still not fully studied [47–49]. In general, NH3 oxidation undergoes a process of gradual dehydrogenation and N coupling to generate nitrogen and water. In absence of advanced characterization methods and auxiliary theoretical calculations, two mechanisms were first enthusiastically proposed and studied, complete or partial dehydrogenation. Dehydrogenation and N coupling make up the whole oxidation process, so there must be a sequence. Oswin and Salomon studied the electrochemical kinetic studies of the oxidation of ammonia on the surface of platinum black, and compared the Tafel slopes of experiments with the theoretical ones based on Temkin Isotherm and Langmuir Isotherm [50]. Distinguished from the gas phase reaction, they thought that ammonia continuously removed three hydrogens on the electrode surface completely, and then two remain N atoms were coupled to generate nitrogen (complete dehydrogenation mechanism, denoted as O-S mechanism, Eq. (2)). (1) O v e r a ll r e a c t i o n : 2 N H 3 + 6 O H - → N 2 + 6 H 2 O (2) O - S m e c h a n i s m : NH 3 * + O H - → NH 2 * + H 2 O + e - NH 2 * + O H - → NH * + H 2 O + e - NH * + O H - → N * + H 2 O + e - 2 N * → N 2 * → N 2 (3) M - G m e c h a n i s m : NH 3 * + ( 3 - x ) O H - → NH x * + ( 3 - x ) H 2 O + ( 3 - x ) e - NH x 1 * + NH x 2 * → N 2 * H y ( y = x 1 + x 2 ) N 2 * H y + y O H - → N 2 * + y H 2 O + y e - N 2 * → N 2 Soon after, Maurer and Gerischer came up with a totally different pathway that oxidation of ammonia occurred by OH-radicals which were simultaneously adsorbed at the same surface sites to generate NH x -radicals (x = 2 or 1) and then form N2H y -molecules (y = 4 or 2) or an N2H3-radical by recombination, and these N2H n continued to dehydrogenate to form nitrogen (partial dehydrogenation mechanism, denoted as M-G mechanism, Eq. (3)) [51]. Maurer and Gerischer’s proposed standpoint points out that NH3 could not dehydrogenate to form N atom because they were so strongly chemisorbed on the surface that no recombination was possible. And once happened, they could block the catalytic sites, causing the catalysts poisoning. Knowing the fact that Nads species are strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, M-G mechanism has been accepted by the researchers [47,52,53]. Recent years has witnessed the rationality through rather convinced electrochemical data and in situ characterization methods [54]. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE), differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) study, surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) study, and infrared spectroscopy (IR) have provided the direct evidence such as the presence of N2H n species in AOR, as well as the strong adsorption energy of Nads species. 2.2 Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) study RRDE is an efficient electrochemical analysis method that can eliminate or reduce the effect of surface mass transfer to study the current density distribution on the electrode surface, and it can detect the existence form and amount of electrode reaction products, especially intermediate products. To better understand the reaction mechanism and relational intermediates, rotating disk electrode (RDE) and RRDE were first to be utilized to elucidate further information on the mechanism of AOR on a platinum anode by Miura et al. [55]. Firstly, they carried out the experiments on the RDE (Pt disk) and found the decreased current density both in terms of LSV and potentiostatic current–time curves. RRDE (Pt disk and Ni ring) was then employed to probe the mechanisms behind such results and a noticeable ring current was observed at −0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl. To identify this ring current, NH2OH, a potential intermediate of AOR, was oxidized at Ni electrode and a similar current curve appeared, proving such current in Ni ring may belong to the NH2OH oxidation. Other from the potential NH2OH oxidation current density, the observed cathodic ring current can be attributed to the reduction of NO x transported from the disk electrode. These results demonstrated the powerful ability of RRDE to detect the possible reaction intermediates NH2OH and NO x of AOR. With the aim to explore transport phenomena associated with the AOR, Botte et al. also performed this reaction using a RDE [56]. The catalyst Pt was electrodeposited over a nickel disk electrode at different time and temperatures to form the working electrodes. The RDE-LSV curves (Fig. 1 a) and corresponding plot of i P (peak current density) vs. v 1/2 (the square root of the scan rate) plot are presented in Fig. 1(b), respectively. The liner relationship between i P and v 1/2 indicates a completely diffusion-controlled process for the AOR. The diffusion coefficient (D NH3) for ammonia was calculated to be 1.217 × 10−9 cm2 s−1, which was almost four orders of magnitude lower than the one determined using the Wilke and Chang correlation for NH3 in water (2.4 × 10−5 cm2 s−1). However, the parallelism of the Levich equation with the RDE experimental results at different scan rates and theoretical Levich curve certificates the rationality of D NH3 in their work (Fig. 1c). Based on these, the plot between the experimental normalized current vs. the dimensionless scan rate is displayed in Fig. 1(d). Irregular shape of experimental data strongly suggests that the AOR currents observed for the tested settings are not achieving the steady state. Based on the RDE and mathematical study, the AOR could proceed fast enough to avoid the stabilization of the concentration profiles in the diffusion layer, and achieve a steady state current. RRDE gives us the opportunity to study the reaction kinetics and mass transfer at electrode surface, providing a powerful basis for the study of the mechanism. However, RRDE still lacks essential evidence of surface intermediates, and it is necessary to explore the electrochemical process in combination with other methods. 2.3 Differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) study DEMS is a comprehensive method that combines electrochemical and mass spectrometry to detect in situ volatile substances on the electrode surface. As an on-line analytical tool, DEMS is capable to identify the nature of the intermediates or products during the reaction and provide the direct evidence for some proposed mechanisms. AOR was first studied through DEMS by Vielstich et al. [57]. Their most significant and profound DEMS results revealed that ammonia could be oxidized to nitrogen at peak potential and NO x could be obtained at higher potential region where PtO x could form. This spectral data provided intuitive evidence for studying the mechanism of AOR. More detailed experiments with DEMS started by Gootzen et al. [58]. They combined DEMS and cyclic voltammetry to determine the intermediates of AOR on the platinized platinum surface. A quantitative analysis of experimental data has given information on the coverage of the adsorbates such as N2H y . The adsorbate coverage can be calculated according to Eq. (4): (4) θ = Δ Q o x / n Q H 0 ΔQ ox is calculated by subtracting calculated current–time curve from the measured current–time curve, standing for the charge that is transferred during the experiment that has not resulted in the formation of N2 but in the formation of adsorbed species. Q H 0 is the charge involved in the desorption of a monolayer of adsorbed hydrogen, while n = 3 (Nads), n = 2 (NHads) and n = 1 (NH2,ads). As shown in Fig. 1(e), the coverage of Nads quickly rises to platform 0.6 at low voltage and then drops, indicating the possibility that the adsorbate does not consist of N but of NH or NH2 at low potentials. Furthermore, the number of electrons per N2 molecule is also estimated calculating from the measured ratio i/i mass,N2, as shown in Fig. 1(f). Theoretically, the number of electron transfers per N2 molecule is 6, clearly seem at low potential. However, it increased to almost 13 at higher potential, exhibiting the existence of nitrogen oxides as Eqs. (5–7). (5) 2 N H 3 → N 2 + 6 H + + 6 e - (6) N H 3 + 7 O H - → N O 2 - + 5 H 2 O + 6 e - (7) N H 3 + 9 O H - → N O 3 - + 6 H 2 O + 8 e - Compared to RRDE test, DEMS provides more intuitive evidence of intermediates or products such as N2 and NO x of AOR. However, limited by the test conditions of DEMS, only the final products that can be desorbed from the electrode can be detected, and it lacks the understanding of the real state of the electrode surface. From this point of view, in situ spectroscopy is a very advantageous method, such as infrared spectrum and Raman spectrum. 2.4 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) study The specific diversification of AOR was also explored with the help of in situ FTIR [59]. In situ attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IR) was utilized by Eguchi et al. to investigate the electrochemical behavior of Pt electrode in AOR [60]. Observed three characteristic absorption bands at 1269, 1497–1508, and 1662–1674 cm−1 are ascribed to NH2 wagging of N2H4 (v 11), bridged NO stretch (v 2) and HNH bend of NH3 (v 4), respectively (Fig. 1g). Such characteristic absorption bands advantageously proved that N2H4 was the main intermediates of AOR and NO x could form during this process. These spectral evidences strongly support the M-G mechanism and it is consistent with the conclusion of DEMS. In addition, the potential dependence of the current density of Pt electrode and the intensity of three characteristic bands are shown in Fig. 1(h). The intensity of peak representing NH3 (blue) decreased with the increasing of potential, and the peak of N2H4 (red) increased first and then decreased along with the increasing peak intensity of NO (green), indicating the activity of N2H4 and formation of nitrogen oxides at higher potential. This conclusion is also consistent with previous work [59]. 2.5 Surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) study As a molecular vibrational spectrum, Raman spectroscopy can reflect the characteristic structure of molecules. As shown in in situ electrochemistry, the species adsorbed on the electrode surface can be detected in real time. However, Raman signals are very weak, and Raman spectroscopy on surface-adsorbed species always requires some enhancement effects such as SERS. Koper et al. used SERS for the first time to study the AOR process at gold and palladium electrodes, revealing the nature of surface-adsorbed species [61]. The sets of potential-dependent SERS spectra on gold show a clear band at 365–385 cm−1, which are ascribed to metal-ammonia stretching vibration (v M−NH3). To investigate the nature of metal-ammonia complex, they conducted the H/D isotope experiment that AOR was carried out in H2O and D2O. The computed isotopic redshift of NH3/ND3 is 30 cm−1, which is much larger than experimental one (15–20 cm−1) (Fig. 3 l and m). In addition, such v M-NH3 feature spectra band disappeared at negative potential as well as the loss of this band when electrode transferred into ammonia free solution was indicative of ammonia desorption. These observed Raman spectra indicate the low affinity between gold and ammonia and there is no evidence that atonic N formed during AOR process. In the case of palladium electrodes, the observed isotopic redshift (30 cm−1) coincides with the computed one (30 cm−1), indicating the surface adsorption of ammonia (Fig. 3i and j). It can also be proved that this band appears during the negative scan. Interestingly, the Raman band at increasing potential (0.9 V vs. RHE) shows zero D/H isotopic effect at 462–464 cm−1 (Fig. 1k), which arises from metal-nitrogen (v M-N) stretching mode. This band indicated that ammonia was completely dehydrogenated to Nads species in this condition. Combined with their previous work, the author confirmed the existence of Nads specie in the palladium electrodes and this surface specie was inactive for the formation of N2, supporting the rationality of M-G mechanism. As gold and palladium are not considered to be good catalysts towards AOR, it is essential to choose some good candidates such as platinum to explore the AOR with Raman spectrum. Pt is the best pure metal catalysts for AOR, and the perfect model to probe the mechanism. Pérez et al. utilized SERS to research the AOR process in the nanostructured Pt and revealed the existence of azide anion (*N3 −) [62]. The noticeable peak at 2007 and 435 cm−1 with increasing potential appeared in the both electrocatalysis system and NaN3 solution represented this anion might be the intermediate of AOR. The author marked the recombination *NH3 and *N2H n (n = 2, 3, 4) responsible for the emergence of *N3 −. This discovery not only supports the M-G mechanism, but also proposes a reaction path parallel to this. Based on above studies, it is quite likely that AOR follows the M-G mechanism. After partial dehydrogenation of ammonia, N-N coupling is happened first, and then completely dehydrogenated to obtain N2. At the same time, Nads could be formed by complete dehydrogenation and poison the catalyst as it was strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and this adsorbed Nads could be oxidized into NO x at higher potential. Although some questions still exist and there is no more direct evidence, these results have laid a solid foundation for future work. 3 The electrocatalysts applied towards AOR Catalysts acting as the essential part of electrochemical process have been always the focus of attention [63–66]. Understanding the mechanism reveals the guidelines to design efficient catalysts for various reactions. In the AOR process, the main factor effecting the catalytic property is the affinity for Nads and other intermediates such as NH2,ads and N2H x ,ads, and these affinities determine the reaction rate and the composition of products [47]. In order to achieve the high reaction rate (high peak current density), exact product (only N2) and remarkable stability (high resistance of Nads), strategies of catalysts design have been explored in recent years, involving topography control [67] interface engineering [68] microstructure regulation [69] and alloy design [70]. The catalysts for AOR can be classified into two main kinds: Homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Homogeneous catalysts are mainly metal-complexes with remarkable efficiency and selectivity due to their unique structures. The metal-complexes could regulate coordination structure to tune the electrocatalytic property, and NH3 molecule could tightly and directly bind with metal center, ensuring almost 100% use of catalysts. However, unsatisfied shortcomings including high cost, toxic effects and recycling difficulties have severely hindered its development. The focus on the heterogeneous catalysts has always been the point with the advantages of easy preparation, low toxicity, high catalytic property, and recyclability. In this section, the catalysts applied towards AOR will be reviewed and some problems will be discussed. 3.1 Metal-organic complexes electrocatalysts To realize the electrocatalytic conversion of ammonia into nitrogen with transition metal complexes, an anticipated key process is the formation of metal-imide and -nitride complexes multiple-bond species. Late transition metal-imide and -nitride complexes have become the potential homogeneous catalysts due to their weak metal-nitrogen bond caused by the d-electrons of the metal center occupying the anti-bonding orbitals of the metal-nitrogen π bond [71,72]. Buhr and Taube were the first to investigate the AOR by metal–organic complexes in 1979 and revealed that N2 can be obtained in the μ-N2-bridged product [(Os(NH3)4(CO))2N2]4+ from [Os(NH3)5(CO)]2+ [73]. The discovery that dinuclear Ru-organic complexes could be oxidized to N2 was found by Meyer et al. They proved [(bpy)2(NH3)RuORu(NH3)(bpy)2]4+ could be oxidized to N2 through hydrazine pathway [74,75]. Smith et al. reported that [Ru(trpy)(dmabpy)(NH3)][PF6]2 could efficiently transform ammonia into N2 in DMF and the potential was lowered by 300 mV compared to the NH3 that was catalyzed in glass carbon electrode [76]. Mechanism and isotopic labeling experiments confirmed the occurrence of NH3 oxidation and the first step of AOR was the one electron oxidation of Ru-organic complexes. Although Ru-organic complexes are considered the best candidates, iron also shows a competitive capability towards AOR. Peters et al. have reported iron(II) tris(2-pyridylmethyl)amine (TPA) bis-ammine triflate ([(TPA)Fe(NH3)2]OTf2) for efficient AOR in acetonitrile [77]. Their unearthing started the exploration of splendid molecular catalysts and a host of complexes owned the ability to oxidize ammonia to N2 whether it was going through the hydrazine pathway [78–80] or the nitride pathway [81,82]. Smith’s work had confirmed the truth of the AOR activity of ruthenium-nitride complexes, but it’s still not sensible due to the existing ammonia molecular ligand. Nishibayashi et al. established the AOR homogeneous catalysis system with ruthenium complexes supported by 2,2′-bipyridyl-6,6′-dicarboxylate ligands [83]. The N2 was successfully detected when ammonia mare treated with a triarylamine radical (NH4OTf) as an oxidant and 2,4,6-collidine as a base in the presence of the ruthenium catalysts. The overpotential of this system is estimated to be 0.75 V, which is much higher than that of the most efficient catalyst Pt while it is more competitive than the most studied Ni-based catalysts. DFT calculation proves the reliability of the authors’ proposed plausible reaction pathway which goes through a bimetallic nitride-nitride coupling process. This suggests Ru complexes provide an alternative to promote the evolution of energy transition. 3.2 Precious metal-based electrocatalysts 3.2.1 Pure metal electrocatalysts 3.2.1.1 Platinum Although there are tremendous investigations to seek an AOR electrocatalyst both efficiently and inexpensively, Pt and its derivatives are still occupying the top position (rows 1–10 in Table 2 ) [84–87]. As theoretical calculation research has been mentioned below, platinum not only presents a lower initial potential, but also a higher Nads oxidation potential and a lower NH2,ads dimerization activation energy. These features make Pt still the standard and model electrode for studying AOR. For example, early mechanism researches were developed on Pt electrodes. Apart from the establishment of O-S and M-G mechanism, Zambonin et al. studied the electrocatalytic activity of Pt for AOR in (Na, K)NO3 equimolar melt, and put forward the ammonia oxidation and reduction mechanism in this circumstances [88]. The pursuit of preeminent Pt-based AOR electrocatalysts can be roughly divided into several aspects: Improved intrinsic properties of Pt, better interface engineering and optimized preparation methods, etc. The main intrinsic property of Pt which effects the AOR performance comes from its structure sensitivity that AOR takes place almost exclusively on Pt (100) plain among its three basic plains (100) (110) and (111) [70,89–100]. Feliu et al. reported the independence between the activity and the arrangements of (100) sites of platinum [97]. Remarkable peak current density can be detected in case of Pt (100), and only few reactivity in Pt (110) and Pt (111), illustrating clearly the structure sensitive process. More details about the structure sensitivity of AOR were further explored and demonstrated that the ammonia molecules were also able to discriminate the width of the (100) terraces and the density of steps with (100) symmetry. To better understand the structure sensitivity of AOR, Rosca and Koper characterized the process on Pt(111) and (100) by voltammetry, chronoamperometry and in situ infrared spectroscopy [94]. They revealed that initial stage of AOR on (111) plain occured at potentials corresponding to the double-layer region, leading to the formation of *NH and possible *N species. Correspondingly, it takes place at hydrogen underpotential deposition (Hupd) region, and only NH2 adsorbate can be observed on (100) plain. Combined the above results, it is quite clearly that the NO x detected in the electrode comes from the further oxidation of *N species. This is quite helpful to understand the structural sensitivity of AOR that the dimerization of *N species in (111) is a very sluggish process, showing low AOR activity. The fascinating performance at (100) is attributed to the stabilizing effect of *NH2 and then form *N2H4. The aim of basic researches is to promote the development of practical technology. Understanding the knowledge of structure sensitivity, nanoparticles with (100) orientation are assumed to be practical catalysts, and nanocubes or hexahedrons are mainly oriented with this crystal plane. Based on this understanding, the synthesis of Pt nanocubes is an effective way to improve the catalytic activity [87,89,99,101–103]. Feliu et al. prepared the Pt nanocubes through a concise, fast, and scalable way with HCl modification [104]. They found that Pt nanocubes could be easily prepared by changing amounts of HCl in the water phase of the microemulsion. The increased area of the Hupd at 0.37 V (vs. RHE) (This region is characteristic of the presence of (100) steps and terrace borders.) in voltammetric profile shows the increasing (100) sites in Pt nanoparticles (Fig. 2a). As shown in Fig. 2(b), cubic Pt nanostructures are successfully synthesized with size of 12–14 nm. When HCl% is 25%, the nanocubes exhibit highest (100) occupation ratio, as detected by Ge irreversible adsorption (solid black squares) and hydrogen adsorption/desorption deconvolution (open red circles) (Fig. 2c). Due to the (100) plain sensibility, the optimal AOR property (1.96 mA cm−2) is achieved in 25%-HCl sample (Fig. 2d). To further find out this structural sensitivity, the author normalized current density of Pt(2n − 1,1,1) single crystals ((100) terraces with (111) steps, and compared to the Pt nanoparticles (Fig. 2e). Obviously, the longer (100) terrace width (The atomic model is shown in Fig. 2f) leads to the better AOR activity, indicating the importance of (100) terrace width. In addition to the plain control of catalysts, surface active area is an important element affecting catalytic activity. For instance, Amrein et al. fabricated a Pt black electrode by electrodeposition and achieved a peak current density 22.5 mA cm−2 at scan rate of 5 mV s−1 [105]. Their results reveal that observed elevated property is attributable to both an increased effective surface area of the electrode and the enhanced electron transfer reaction. Interface engineering involves multiple aspects and we will focus on the issue of catalyst supports here because of their commonality [106]. The selection of supports plays a significant role in regulating the electronic structure [107–109] enhancing mass transmission [110] and adjusting the reaction environment [111]. The selection and optimization of supports also play an important role in AOR process. As the proton acceptor, the local concentration of OHads plays a crucial role in the AOR process [112] which can be adjusted by supports. Metal oxides are deemed to be superior OHads supply sources and enhance the reaction where OHads are involved [113–115]. Eguchi et al. explored the enhancement of the adsorption property of the OHads species on over rare earth oxides (RO: CeO2, Y2O3, La2O3, and Sm2O3) (Fig. 3a) [108]. To prepare the composite electrode, Pt is deposited on the mixture of multiwall carbon nanotube (MWNT) and polybenzimidazole (PBI) (Pt/PBI/MWNT) and RO is physically mixed with Pt/PBI/MWNT. Fig. 3(b) exhibits that CeO2 modified Pt catalysts achieved optimal activity and could be explained by the promotion effect of OHads supply. As the oxidation current at 0.75–0.85 V originated from the adsorption of OH or oxidation of Pt surface, the author regards this current as the parameter related to the amount of OHads species on the electrode surface. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the highest AOR current and OH adsorption showed consistency, presenting that OH adsorption had a positive effect on AOR. Further experiments show that the enhancement effect is particularly significant at low OH concentrations and high temperature conditions (60 °C) as shown in Fig. 3(d and e). The same effects were noticed by Baranova et al. that the effects of ITO (Pt/C-ITO (In2O3)9·(SnO2)1) and ATO (Pt/C-ATO (SnO2)9·(Sb2O5)1) oxides were investigated [116]. Electrochemical measurements and DAFC experiments demonstrate the best results in case of Pt/C-ITO. The current density of AOR on Pt/C-ITO is about 2.5, 2.8, and 3.3 times higher than that obtained on Pt/C-ATO, commercial Pt/C (BASF) and Pt/C, respectively. And power density of DAFC shows 37% and 14% higher than those obtained using Pt/C-ATO and Pt/C, respectively. The author attributed this promotion to oxidation or hydroxide species provided by ITO at low potential, which could remove poisonous intermediate Nads and strengthen the process of AOR. The preparation process of the catalyst determines its’ related performance, which is always the significant part of catalyst. A variety of synthetic methods have been developed and optimized to improve the property of electrocatalysts, for example, electrodeposition [117–121] and wet chemical methods [90,99,101,122]. Zhang et al. developed a thermal annealing-potentiodynamic electrodeposition strategy to prepare the hybrid catalysts in which Pt particles are anchored to N-doped graphene (Pt-NG) through electrodeposition [123]. The optimized ratio of graphene oxide (GO) and melamine and the electrodeposition method lead to remarkable content of both pyridinic and graphitic N as well as the smaller particle size of Pt with well distribution, respectively, resulting in the improvement of mass activity. The obtained excellent performance declares this promising method for other graphene-based catalysts. Another synthetic method was reported by Zhong et al. which combined electrodeposition and galvanic replacement [91]. Firstly, flower-like Ni particles were electrodeposited onto a conductive substrate and Pt was loaded on Ni particles by the replacement of a part of Ni. This approach possesses advantages such as free of surfactants binders, reducing agent and capping agents. The maintenance of the flower-like morphology and nanopores along with small sized Pt grains are achieved, leading to mass activity of 75.32 mA mg−1 (2 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C). 3.2.1.2 Other pure metals Considerable onset potential and moderate adsorption energy of corresponding intermediates compared to Pt, Ir is also considered as a potential electrocatalyst towards AOR. However, other metals show low AOR activity in case of single metal [124] and only theoretical studies have been conducted to explore the instinct reason. Theoretical calculation is also a powerful tool to proof the hypothetical mechanism advanced on the base of experimental phenomenon and data. It can establish a theoretical model that is closest to the actual system, and calculate the relevant physical parameters, providing a theoretical basis for the hypothesis. Mavrikakis et al. reported a study of AOR on a series of close-packed facets of Au, Ag, Cu, Pt, Pd, Ni, Ir, Rh, Co, Os, Ru, and Re using a first-principles density functional theory (DFT) [125]. They performed the Sabatier analysis to predict the operating potentials of the feasible intermediate transformation process on the specific surface of specific metal. DFT calculation results reveal that M-G mechanism is more favorable than N-N mechanism (O-S mechanism) (for Pt, at room temperature, the rate constant for N-N bond formation, the rate-determining step, is approximately 20 orders of magnitude higher for the G-M mechanism). Taking the affinity of metal and N as index, all mentioned metals are divided into three groups: Pt, metals binding N weaker than Pt (Cu, Ag, Au and Pd) and stronger (Ni, Ir, Co, Rh, Ru, Os and Re). From the prediction that the minimum-energy pathway that Pt goes through is the deprotonation of NH3 to NH2, dimerization of NH2 species to hydrazine (H2NNH2), and then successive deprotonation to N2. For the metals bind N weaker as Cu, the feasible rate determine step is N-N formation and the onset potential is 1.2 V, showing an unpleasant activity, and the same results happen in Ag and Au. Although the onset potential for Pd is 0.52 V (for O-S mechanism) and 0.26 V (for M-G mechanism), the difficulty in forming hydrazine (The hydrazine formation barrier is 1.57 eV for Pd, but only 1.07 eV for Pt) seriously hinders AOR process [47]. In the case of high N affinity, Ni and Co present rather low onset potential 0.33 V and 0.12 V, respectively, but sluggish kinetics of hydrazine formation which limits the reaction rate. For Rh, Ru, Os and Re, the robust affinity of Nads leads to poisoning of Nads at all operated potential. The predicted onset potential for Ir is 0.32 V, as low as other metals and it owns modest hydrazine formation barrier (1.21 eV), these factors make it a possible candidate for AOR and it is active for N2 formation, experimentally. Comprehensive theoretical study of the AOR mechanism on platinum surfaces was also conducted by Ishikawa et al. through a combined first-principles molecular dynamics/density functional theory [126]. Their study showed that AOR followed the O-S mechanism at moderate potential (>0.5 V) and M-G mechanism dominated at low potential region (potential demarcation point: 0.5 V). The potential influences on the adsorption energy of intermediates, determining whether NH2(top) dimerization (M-G mechanism) or oxidation of NH2(bridge) (O-S mechanism) happens at applied potential. They also explored the facet sensitivity of Pt towards AOR, presenting the results that the catalytic inactivity of Pt (111) and Pt (110) surfaces is attributed to poisoning of the surfaces by strongly adsorbed N(hollow). 3.2.2 Pt-based binary or ternary alloys To overcome the issues that Pt faced in terms of limited reserves and high cost along with the pursuit of higher performance catalysts, the effects between Pt and other elements in Pt-based binary or ternary alloy have been investigated. Alloying with suitable metal could tune the surface electronic structure for better intermediates adsorption energy and lower reaction energy barrier (rows 11–21 in Table 2) [127,128]. With the aim of seeking suitable element, a series of metals have been explored and can be classified into two groups: precious metals (Ir, Ru, Pd, Rh, Eu etc.) and nonprecious metals (Ni, Cu etc.) (Fig. 4 ) [124,129,130]. As mentioned above, Ir possesses great potential but it is still unsatisfied [124]. However, PtIr alloy presented amazing catalytic property in AOR and received great attention in recent years [131–134]. In general, there are a verity types of PtIr alloy including fully alloyed Pt-Ir, partially alloyed Pt-Ir, and nanocomposites ranging from Ir adatom modified Pt to non-alloyed Pt-Ir oxide. Baranova et al. synthesized the PtIr carbon support nanopaticles through conventional ethylene glycol methods and found that the size distribution and surface chemistry were pH-dependent [135]. Neutral environment leads to average size of 2.9 nm and the formation of Pt(0), Ir(0) and Ir oxides/hydroxides on the surface (PtIr (1)), while higher pH causes to bi-modal distribution of particle sizes with maxima at 1.8 and 3.4 nm and the presence of Pt and Ir in several oxidation states (PtIr (2)). The electrochemical measurements were conducted in 1 M KOH and 0.5 M NH4OH and CV curves displayed an approximately 100 mV of overpotential decrease for PtIr (1) compared to monometallic Pt (Fig. 4a and b). CV curves in 1 M KOH show typical behavior of polycrystalline platinum and no obvious difference in PtIr (1) and PtIr (2). However, noticeable advance of onset potential and peak current density was detected in PtIr (1). They attributed the catalytic property difference between PtIr (1) and PtIr (2) to the surface valence of Pt and Ir as PtIr (2) showed little amount of metallic surface Pt and Ir due to the blocked sites for AOR caused by excess of the surface oxygenated species. Their studies indicated that the significance of PtIr alloy in AOR process. To further improve the property of PtIr alloy, Hu’s group synthesized PtIr nanocubes and revealed the preference of AOR on PtIr (100) plane (Fig. 4c) [134]. However, the relationship between the structure of PtIr alloy and their enhanced activity is still vague and the reason why Ir can reduce the overpotential of AOR need to be solved. Guay et al. have made some progress in this direction [136]. They employed crossed-beam pulsed laser deposition to prepare Pt x Ir100− x alloy films and studied the influence of Ir. Conventional views that surface adsorbed N could be removed at low potential was confirmed by the experiments expanded at different potential window (Fig. 4d) [137]. AOR was also carried out in different potential window. As shown in Fig. 4(e) showed that the peak current density changed slightly at sharp widow (−0.02 V to 0.7 V), suggesting no Nads poisoning below 0.7 V. Moderate window (−0.02 V to 0.83 V) presented a decreasing current density due to Nads poisons. However, an increasing peak current density appeared at wider widow (−0.02 V to ≈1.2 V) where PtO x formed, proving that as-formed PtO x at high potential was responsible for the removal or oxidation of Nads poisons. Combined the results in their work and previous investigation [138] the author thought that Ir could act like Pt to form IrO x at moderate potential and oxidize Nads poisons into NO x , thus improve the poisons resistance of PtIr alloys. Apart from the PtIr alloys, PtAu (Fig. 4g) [140], PtRh (Fig. 4h) [122,141] PtRu (Fig. 4i) [142] PtEu [130] and PtPd [68,143] alloys also show superior AOR activity than pure Pt. It is postulated that the presence of Rh along with Pt would realize a greater number of unused active sites on the Pt surface for NH3 oxidation by Botte et al. [122]. Electronic interaction between Rh and Pt together with the excellent activity toward OH− adsorption for Rh is attributed to the improvement of catalytic property. Silva et al. prepared the PtRh/C catalysts with different ratios by borohydride reduction method and evaluated their electrochemical behaviors for DAFC [141]. When the ratio of Pt and Rh is 90:10, DAFC displays the highest power density 5.37 mW cm−2 at the condition of 3 M NH4OH and 3 M KOH. The performance of PhRu alloys in DAFC was studied by Baranova and found that the addition of 10 at% of Ru was beneficial of both open circuit voltage (OCV, 20 mV promotion) and power density (10% elevation) compared to Pt/C [142]. The role Ru played in the system was detected by products analysis and the concentration of nitrite and nitrate was twice higher than that of Pt/C, showing a possibility that Ru could oxidize Nads poisons into nitrite and nitrate thus improving the activity. This reasonable explanation has been mentioned above as Ru could adsorb OH– at low potential and oxidize Nads poisons possibly. In the case of coin metals, considering that Au shows an N adsorption energy of −162 kJ mol−1 (weaker than Pt: −394 kJ mol−1), Assumpção et al. explored the practicality of PtAu alloys in DAFC [140]. The 60% higher power density and 20% for peak current density in case of Pt70Au30/C relative to Pt/C, and the contribution of Au is assumed to be the decrease of poisoning on catalysts surface due to its lower N adsorption energy. Pt-based ternary alloys also get the potential ability to both improve the current density and reduce the overpotential. Binary alloy PtIr catalysts exhibited promising activity, however, limited applied potential and current density along with high cost and scarcity have hampered its development. To push the development of AOR catalysts forward, the introduction of the third metal such as Ni and Zn into PtIr alloys seems promising [139,144]. Possessing the favorable theoretical onset potential (0.33 vs. 0.28 V of Pt), Ni is deemed to be promising candidate for AOR. However, the relatively high energy barrier for crucial intermediate hydrazine formation (1.39 vs. 1.09 eV of Pt) makes Ni (metallic Ni) inactive towards AOR. Inspired by the instinct properties of Ni, Wu et al. prepared PtIrNi ternary alloy supported on a composite support consisting of porous SiO2 and carboxyl-functionalized carbon nanotube (PtIrNi/SiO2-CNT-COOH) [144]. A remarkable result was demonstrated as high current density (124 A g−1) and low onset potential (0.4 V vs. RHE) at 25 °C was achieved and further reached 1382.7 A g−1 and 0.32 V at 80 °C, respectively. One of the key factors is that the combination of SiO2 and carboxyl-functionalized carbon nanotube provides abundant OH for active sites and ensures high conductivity for electron transfer. On the other hand, the role of Ni was confirmed by DFT calculation, as the lower thermodynamic barrier for the dehydrogenation of *NH2 to *NH was obtained and the group d-orbital of density of states shifts up in energy (−1.97 to −1.87 eV), leading to favorable manner for AOR. With the assistance of previous researches of Pt-based alloys for AOR, a comprehensive, critical and might not be exactly right understanding could be established. The biggest problem in AOR currently lies in the adsorption of Nads and blocking the active sites, which leads to the efficiency and stability of the catalyst far from large-scale operation. Pt becomes an essential AOR catalyst because Nads poisoning occurs at higher potentials, while other precious metal exhibit lower overpotentials due to their affinity for N x H y . In order to achieve a lower onset potential and higher peak current density (higher Nads poisoning potential), alloying of Pt with other precious metals is a very effective solution. The key to the effectiveness of this method depended on the potential of OH adsorption on different metal surfaces, and that the OH adsorbed by the second metal, which was easier to adsorb OH at low potential, could oxidize and remove Nads poison on the surface of Pt, such as Ir, Rh and Ru. In other word, the affinity of different metals for OH has close relationship with their catalytic performance of AOR. However, a serious hinder in front of the practical application of Pt-based alloys is that the introduction of second metal would beget a decrease of peak current density and only at suitable potential interval alloys would surpass monometallic Pt [70]. Gullon et al. received such results at a series PtM (M = Ir, Rh, Pd, Ru) alloys, ascribing to occupation of Pt (100) surface sites by M and the decrease of dimension of the (100) domains. The loss of most active sites made AOR occur in an unfavorable way, resulting in slow reaction rate. Although a relatively low overpotential was achieved in Ir and Rh, the decrease of current density at peak potential indicated the limitations of alloying methods at the condition of AOR. This fact reminds that the cooperation of second metal should take various factors into consideration such as the ratio of metal content, morphology of nanoparticles and potential applied, to accelerate the reaction rate and maximize the efficiency of catalysts. 3.3 Non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts Many efforts have been made to seek the alternatives to Pt because of its practical limitations in term of high cost and rapid inactivation [23]. As what we talked above, transition metals show insensitivity for ammonia oxidation although its competitive theoretical onset potential due to rather high energy barrier for hydrazine formation [125]. Several experiments have been conducted and proved their inactivity towards AOR (rows 1–6 in Table 3 ) [61,145,146]. Interestingly, compared to other transition metals, in the case of Ni, considerable anodizing current is observed in the presence of ammonia at high potential where Ni is oxidized into Ni3+. This current is attributed to ammonia oxidation and the formed Ni3+ which is assumed to be the active sites for AOR [8,23,147–149]. Kapałka et al. investigated the electrochemical behavior of ammonia at Ni/Ni(OH)2 electrode from the perspective of electrolyte pH, chronoamperometric study and product analysis [150]. The symmetrical peaks A1/C1 showing in Fig. 5 (a) belong to the redox activity of Ni2+/Ni3+ and the peak A2 is ascribed to the oxidation of ammonia. Positive potential for the peak A2 indicates that ammonia oxidation takes place upon the formation of Ni3+ and the increasing density of A1 and A2 with the concentration of ammonia while the peak C1 remains unchanged, proving that the oxidation of ammonia might go through the Eq. (8) rather than Eq. (9) [151,152]. The liner relationship between current density of A2 and the concentration of ammonia suggests that oxidation of ammonia on Ni/Ni(OH)2 is controlled by diffusion. The influence of pH can be seen in Fig. 5(b) and large enhancement of activity at high pH indicates the form of ammonia that can be oxidized to NH3 molecular instead of NH4 +. (8) N i 3 + ( N i O O H ) + N H 3 → N i 3 + ( N i O O H ) N H 3 , a d s → N i 3 + ( N i O O H ) + N 2 (9) N i 3 + ( N i O O H ) + N H 3 → N i 3 + ( N i O O H ) N H 3 , a d s → N i 2 + + N 2 Another important information can be acknowledged in Fig. 5(c). The continuous increase of the current density with subsequent ammonia injections indicates that the Ni/Ni(OH)2 electrode is not deactivated during ammonia oxidation even at high ammonia concentrations. However, the products analysis provided the formation of by-products nitrate (Fig. 5d) and the electrode corrosion was observed, suggesting the limitation of Ni/Ni(OH)2 electrode. As another important form of Ni2+, the AOR property on NiO has been studied by Almomani et al. [153]. However, XPS spectrum reveals the existence of a film of Ni(OH)2 in the surface and it is responsible for the oxidation of ammonia. However, Baranova et al. carried out the comprehensive research about the effect of Pd on Ni for ammonia oxidation and proposed another conclusion. They investigated the property of Ni nanoparticles with extremely low Pd content (1 at%) [155]. The active component (Ni(OH)2) is accomplished by 200 cycles’ CV in 1 M NaNO3 at the surface of NiPd. For the reaction mechanism, distinguished from what Kapałka has found, the AOR performed in different concentration of ammonia as shown in Fig. 5(e) and it was noticed that an increase of the response of the Ni(II)/Ni(III) redox process at low concentrations (25 to 75 mM) indicated a direct electron transfer mechanism (Eq. (5)). However, at high concentrations condition (≥150 mM), the redox response decreased and the peak of ammonia oxidation positively shifted (Fig. 5f). These showed the possibility of the indirect pathway (Eq. (6)) of AOR that NH3 could react with NiOOH, which was a non-Faraday process. During this process, although the concentration of ammonia has been increased, there is limited NiOOH formation and it becomes the bottleneck of the reaction. The essential difference between the different results is that the effect of NiOOH is different, which is the catalysts in direct electron transfer mechanism and turns into reactant in indirect pathway. Although there are doubts and lack of solid evidence, these works provide effective guidance for understanding the catalytic mechanism of Ni-based catalyst. With the understanding of association between Ni and ammonia oxidation, the oxidation of Ni2+ into Ni3+ is essential for AOR. As a promising catalyst for OER [156–158] and biomass upgrading [159,160] Ni-based materials have attracted tremendous attention in recent years. Same methods have been utilized to improve the catalytic performance of Ni for AOR, such as the induction of second metal. Cu is believed to be a superior catalyst for AOR theoretically [125] so it is rational to choose Cu as the dopant into Ni [161,162]. Tao et al. leaded Cu into Ni layered hydroxides (LHs) through facile hydrothermal methods (Fig. 6 a) [163]. The formed hierarchical NiCu LHs nanowires on carbon fibre cloth enhanced significantly the catalytic performance for AOR, as shown in Fig. 6(b). Apart from the remarkable activity and stability confirmed by CVs and step-by-step injections experiments (Fig. 6c), the smaller Tafel slop also indicated faster kinetic rate. The authors also explored the specialty of Cu by introducing other transition metal (Co, Fe, Zn, Mn, Cr) into Ni LHs and interestingly found no improvement towards AOR. Improved active sites (increased specific capacitance) and possible formation of Ni1− x Cu x OOH are responsible for the advancement of activity. Although lots of strives have been done to quest the nature of Ni-based materials catalyzing AOR, the essence is still ambiguous and unintelligible. The exploration of mechanism occupied the most important but difficult part of the reaction. Preliminary aspects of the Ni catalyzed AOR have been proposed, however, no details or direct evidences were observed. For better understanding of this system, more detailed information needs to be found such as the nature of intermediates in the electrode and relationship between catalysts structure and catalytic property. To achieve this, in situ methods are also potential to gain insight into the in-site changes in reaction and provide valuable information of mechanism. Furthermore, the issue of corrosion is also a problem that cannot be ignored. 3.4 Other electrodes A few of other electrodes for oxidation of ammonia have also been reported to date. As a traditional OER standard catalyst, IrO2 is also utilized as metal electro-winning and the oxidation of small molecule organic compounds [169,170]. The electrochemical behavior of ammonia on electrochemically grown anodic iridium oxide film (AIROF) electrode was conducted by Kapałka et al. [52]. The AOR activity performed in 100 mM NH4ClO4 + 1 M NaClO4 + NaOH at pH 9 showed onset potential at 0.25 V vs. Hg/Hg2SO4/K2SO4 (MSE) with current density of 2.7 mA cm−2 at scan rate of 50 mV s−1. They also explored the thermal and electrochemical preparation of IrO2 electrodes for AOR [171] and found thermally decomposed iridium oxide films (TDIROF) presented different behaviors to AIROF as TDIROF would be deactivated during the electrolysis while AIROF was the opposite. Combined electrochemical results and previous work, they provided the explanation that the surface experienced fast regeneration during the potential scan in the case of AIROF. Same as Pt-based catalysts, alloying with other metals could significantly increase the catalytic activity of Ir, such as Ru [172] and Rh [173]. Wang et al. prepared ammonia sensor based on the carbon supported IrCo alloy through NaBH4 reduction methods [166]. The fabricated electrodes demonstrated high sensitivity and quick response for ammonia compare to Ir/C and commercial PtRu/C. A reasonable interpretation for the improvement was that Co could change the crystal and electronic structure of Ir towards AOR favorable environment and could reduce the use of previous metal. CuO-modified TiO2 electrode was prepared by Hung and Mishra et al. and they investigated its application in AOR [174,175]. Compared traditional electrocatalytic system, CuO-TiO2 electrode was test in an acidic environment (0.5 M H2SO4) and showed a huge enhancement of activity relative to TiO2. However, further studies about the active sites of CuO-TiO2 and the difference about mechanism between acidic and alkaline environments need to be done. Carbon materials have also received much attention in term of AOR (rows 7, 8 in Table 3). Boron-doped diamond (BDD) electrode was first probed by Compton et al. in the electro-oxidation of ammonia in 0.1 M KCl aqueous solution with 0.1% ammonia gas bubbled [168]. Among the involved carbon materials electrodes (glassy carbon (GC), edge plane pyrolytic graphite (EPPG), basal plane pyrolytic graphite (BPPG) and highly ordered pyrolytic graphite (HOPG)), BDD showed only observed responses of AOR and revealed that high proportion of edges plane played an important role both in less positive potentials and increasing current density. The graphite has also been researched as a potential candidate for AOR by Udert and Zhang et al. [167,176]. As a kind of cheap and readily available, pollution-free material, graphite possesses the advantages such as prevented formation of chlorinated by-products and less energy input compared to indirect oxidation methods. CV curves indicated that AOR could occur in a moderate potential (1–1.6 V vs. SHE), avoiding the corrosion of graphite and the formation of chlorine. The possibility of practical application of graphite was also confirmed by the potentiostatic electrolysis, which showed anti-toxic effects on Nads and explained the slightly higher surface-specific removal rates than conventional biological surface-based nitrogen removal systems. 4 Direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs) The aim of understanding the mechanism of AOR and its fundamental researches from the aspect of electrocatalysts is to better use this clean and sustainable energy support. Although nitrogen-based energy system suffers from limited research efforts and current restrictions for transportation application that ammonia internal combustion engines require dual-fueling or extreme compression ratios to function [177] the urge for economy and environmental protection along with growing global gross greenhouse gas emissions produced by petroleum-derived liquid fuels-based transportation has made DAFCs attractive [178,179]. Compared to commercially available high-performance hydrogen fuel cells and more researched carbon-based biofuels, DAFCs possess the potential for scalable practical application due to the safer and more convenient transportation [180,181] storage, and higher energy density of ammonia (Thermodynamical and energy comparison of existing various attractive fuel cells are given in Table 4 ). Another significant factor makes ammonia promising pathway is that the cost for ammonia production from wind and renewable electricity is more favorable [182,183]. Once the existing dilemma of rather low power density and open circuit voltage (OCV), the technoeconomic embarrassment [179] is ameliorated, ammonia will greatly promote the progress of human civilization as a non-negligible part of the energy structure. Ammonia has been proposed as fuel for fuel cells in 1960 s based on the KOH electrolytes [191] and a maximum power density of 50 mW cm−2 was achieved at 120 °C using 54 wt% potassium hydroxide aqueous electrolyte in the case of ammonia-air fuel cell [192]. Molten hydroxide electrolyte has also been explored in DAFCs between 200 and 450 °C because of their high ionic conductivity (2.5 S cm−1 at 400 °C) and favorable electrode kinetics [193]. A porous nickel anode and a porous cathode of lithiated nickel oxide were chosen and exhibited a peak power density of 40 mW cm−2. Pt was also applied as the anode material for the molten hydroxide-based ammonia fuel cell at 200–220 °C [194]. However, hydroxide electrolyte based DAFCs suffered from the instability and reduced cell efficiency caused by the reaction between hydroxide and CO2 induced by input air [195]. Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) as the emerging promising choice for hydrogen energy, ammonia-fed SOFCs based on both oxygen ion- (SOFC-O) and proton-conducting electrolytes (SOFC-H) at high temperature have been also reported [196–198]. Regardless of whether it is SOFC-O or SOFC-H, the basis of the working prototype of SOFCs is that NH3 pyrolysis produces H2 into SOFCs and is oxidized to release energy. Thus, the nature of ammonia fed SOFCs turns into hydrogen-based SOFCs and the vital point is the conversion of ammonia and hydrogen, which could be solved by Ni catalysts. Several reports presented the ability that Ni could catalyze the pyrolysis of ammonia to hydrogen at 873 K with nearly 100% conversion rate [197,199,200] (Fig. 7 ). Although SOFCs showed the improved efficiency and power outputs, the specialty for vehicle applications such as fast start-up advantage made cryogenic operating systems more attractive. To get rid of the influence of introduced CO2 and deficiencies in SOFCs, researchers also turned their eyes on the alkaline membrane fuel cells. These alkaline membranes that could be compatible with CO2 showing the great foreground towards DAFCs and previous studies noticed that the introduction of CO2 could improve the fuel cell performance [201]. During the discharge process, as air enters the cathode, O2 is reduced to form OH− as Eq. (10), which is transported to the anode through the alkaline membrane. The ammonia gas entering the anode reacts with the OH– transmitted from the cathode and emits electrons as Eq. (11), completing the AOR process (Eq. (12)). (10) 3 O 2 + 6 H 2 O + 12 e - → 12 O H - (11) 4 N H 3 + 12 O H - → 2 N 2 + 12 H 2 O + 12 e - (12) 4 N H 3 + 3 O 2 → 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O 4.1 High temperature ammonia-fed fuel cells: Ammonia-fed solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) As a type of environmentally friendly electricity generators, SOFCs received increasing attention in recent years both in basic researches and practical applications like stationary power generation [202–204]. Acting the heart of the SOFCs, the study of solid oxide electrolytes determines on the development of batteries. Yttria stabilized zirconia (YSZ, 8 mol% Y2O3, balance ZrO2) solid oxide electrolytes-based ammonia fed SOCF-O has been explored by Wojcik et al. [205]. As the first attempt to use ammonia as the sole fuel and nitrogen as the only product, they applied Fe-based catalysts to catalytic cracking of ammonia and equipped with Ag anode. Interestingly, the assembled cell exhibited the same power density as a hydrogen fuel cell with equivalent supply of pure hydrogen. Meng et al. also reported a high-performance ammonia-fueled SOFCs based on a YSZ thin-film solid electrolyte with the OCV and maximum power density of 1.03 V and 526 mW cm−2, respectively [206]. However, the limitation of high operation temperature (≈ 1000 °C) for YSZ have a profound impact for the practical application of SOFCs that high temperature operation will increase cell cost, severely impact various its components and accelerate life decay. Therefore, to overcome the mentioned drawbacks, calcia stabilized zirconia (CaSZ) [207] and doped cerium oxide (DCO) [208,209] have also been reported. Although SOFC-O displayed excellent prospects for ammonia-based energy system, there were still some problems to be solved. For instance, for the most potential candidate DCO, at an elevated operating temperature, Ce4+ can be reduced to Ce3+ by reducing agent, and the electronic conductance caused by it will reduce the output power and fuel efficiency [210]. On the other hand, NO would appear at higher temperature reported by Wojcik et al [205]. Compared to SOFC-O, proton-conducting SOFCs seem to be an attractive selection due to its competitive conductivity at low temperature [211-213]. Furthermore, the comparative works between SOFC-O and SOFC-H were conducted [214] especially for ammonia fed SOFCs [198]. Leung et al. performed a thermodynamic analysis to compare the theoretical performance of different electrolyte and found that SOFC-H could potentially perform better than SOFC-O [198]. A reasonable explanation is the higher hydrogen partial pressure and lower steam partial pressure in SOFC-H in comparison with an SOFC-O counterpart. At present, the most studied proton-conducting electrolytes are ABO3 perovskite structure oxides. The A position is generally a divalent alkaline earth metal element such as Ba, Sr or Ca, and the B site is generally a tetravalent element such as Ce or Zr [215]. As the most popular perovskite oxides, doped BaCeO3 exhibited great property for ammonia fed SOFCs such as BaCe0.8Gd0.19Pr0.01O3− x (BCGP) [216] BaCe0.8Gd0.2O2.9 (BCGO) [217] BaCe0.8Gd0.2O3− δ (BCG) [218] BaCe0.90Sm0.10O3− δ (BCS) and BaCe0.80Gd0.10Sm0.10O3− δ (BCGS) [219] BaCe0.8Gd0.2O3− δ (BCGO) [220] BaCe0.9Nd0.1O3− δ (BCNO) [221] BaCe1− x Dy x O3− δ [222]. To better understand the mechanism of ammonia fed SOFCs, Ni et al. developed an electrochemical model to study the electrical performance of SOFC-H fed with NH3 and H2 [223]. The same experimental results were reproduced that there was little difference power output between the NH3-fed and the H2-fed SOFC-H with an electrolyte-support configuration but became obvious in the case of anode-supported SOFC-H. Due to the producing of H2O in the cathode, the cathode concentration overpotential is the limiting factor for the H2-fed SOFC-H and an important voltage loss in the NH3-fed SOFC-H. This indicates that the concentration overpotential needs to be concerned when we design practical SOFCs. However, the development and design of SOFCs are still difficult and challenging, including the exploitation of catalysts, optimization of battery components such as gas diffusion layers and electrolyte membranes. The degree of adaptation of the battery to the applicable place also needs to be further optimized and improved. For example, the high-temperature system of the vehicle cell needs to maintain high compatibility with other parts of the car to ensure fast start-up and smooth operation. Furthermore, the construction of stacks in large power stations is also very important to ensure large-scale power supply and raw material replenishment. 4.2 Low temperature DFACs: Hydroxide exchange membranes fuel cells (HEMFCs) Since ammonia oxidation occurs in the form of NH3 molecule, alkaline membrane seems to the optimal selection. Compared to acidic electrolyte membrane-based fuel cells (Proton exchange membranes fuel cells, PEMFCs), the oxidation overpotential of the anode is significantly lower and the electrode reaction activity and rate are improved, so the amount of catalyst required is reduced [224]. Furthermore, the applications of alkaline membrane avoid the formation of H2O and curb the emergence of flooding at the cathode, improving the ORR performance and allowing the utilization of non-precious metal catalyst [225,226]. Organic quaternary ammonium hydroxide linked to polymers in polymer chains provides the aisle for the transportation and delivery of hydroxide [227]. Tao et al. constructed the DAFCs with two kinds of alkaline membrane: A complex of commercial strong basic anion-exchange resin and poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) (AER-PVA), chloroacetyl poly(2,6-dimethyl-1,4-phenylene oxide) (CPPO) [195]. Slightly higher OCV and power density compared to hydrogen fed fuel cell with MnO2 and Cr-decorated Ni (CDN) was observed, showing the potential of HEMFCs. Further HEMFCs have been carried out on other HEM such as terphenyl-based poly(aryl piperidinium) (PAP-TP) [179] AHA [228] AMI 7001 [229] Nafion® 117 [42,140,141,230] and Nafion® 211 [231]. To date, the research focus of HEM-based DAFCs mainly falls on anode catalysts. Eguchi et al. employed commercial hydroxide exchange membranes (A201) with different anodes of Pt/C, PtRu/C, and Ru/C for DAFCs [232]. The order of OCV follows the sequence of PtRu/C > Pt/C > Ru/C showing the ascendancy of PtRu alloy in DAFCs. Besides, Pt [229] and Ni [231] PdIr [230] PtAu [140] PtIr [42] and PtRh [141] also displayed their suitability towards DAFCs. However, the inevitable ammonia crossover remains a significant challenge for DAFCs [60]. As the most common ORR catalysts at cathode in a typical fuel cell, Pt-based catalysts are also highly sensitive to ammonia permeated by the anode, which causes poisoning of the catalyst and decreases cell efficiency. To alleviate this non-negligible problem, Yan et al. reported a potential cathode catalyst (Acta 4020, 3.5 wt% transition metal on carbon support) which presented a better ORR performance in the presence of ammonia [179]. The assembled cell prototype showed a peak energy density of 135 mW cm−2, providing a way to improve the energy efficiency of DAFCs. In addition to the consideration of the cathode catalyst, factors that enable a high-performance of DAFCs need to be concerned in further works to enhance the practical application (Table 5 ). Firstly, efforts are still needed based on anode catalysts, because existing anode catalysts are still limited by issues such as the toxicity of Nads. For the cell devices, unlike hydrogen-based or methanol and ethanol fed fuel cells, the problems of ammonia corrosion on the device are not negligible that ammonia can dissolve with most metals as a strong ligand. Besides, most HEMs have poor stability in alkaline environment under high temperature, limiting its development [233] as AOR is a high temperature favorable process. 5 Summary and outlook The energy and environmental crisis has prompted human society to seek a greener, more environmentally friendly, reliable, and sustainable energy vector. Due to the high on-board cost of hydrogen energy and the difficulty of large-scalability for carbon-based biofuels, ammonia-based energy system has received great attention as the most promising option. As a potential alternative to current fossil fuel-based energy system, ammonia possesses several mesmerizing features such as high energy density, non-polluting products and completely and widely distributed production facilities. In addition, the electrochemical nitrogen removal of nitrogen-containing wastewater and flourish of new ammonia production methods such as photocatalysis [235–237] and electrocatalysis [238–240] also provide the driving forces for AOR. Thus, the urge for clean energy supply has aroused the upsurge of profound investigation for the oxidation of ammonia. Understanding the mechanism of AOR indicates the direction to improve catalytic efficiency of catalysts. Since the proposal of M-G mechanism, the society has gradually revealed the essence of AOR based on in situ techniques such as DEMS, SERS, RRDE (or RDE) and ATR-IR. Researches on AOR on alkaline solution reveal the nature of discovered ammonia oxidation behavior. Pt is denoted as the best pure metal catalyst for AOR due to its low affinity to Nads and suitable dehydrogenation ability which is too high or too low at other metal surface will lead to an unsatisfied performance. Despite the superior performance of Pt, its extremely limitations push the evolvement of improvement. Alloying with other metals provides the opportunities to decrease the Pt loading and for better candidates of AOR catalysts. Precious metals such as Ir, Ru and Pd could significantly reduce the overpotential of AOR while transition metals like Ni, Cu and so on had negligible effects. However, a serious problem is that a decreased of current density is observed in the case of alloy catalysts, indicating further efforts still need be focused. Also, electrochemical results and theoretical calculations show that Pt (110) sites are responsible for AOR, initialing the development of (100) site-dominated nanoparticle catalysts, such as Pt nanocubes and PtM nanocubes (M = Ir, Pd etc.). Besides Pt-based catalysts, Ni also displays great aspects towards AOR with its highly active form Ni3+. Although higher overpotential represents more energy input, Ni-based materials still do a great job in DAFCs. Furthermore, the performance of catalysts was evaluated in DAFCs. Firstly, potassium hydroxide electrolytes were applied and showed the potential of ammonia fed fuel cell and molten hydroxide electrolytes were explored due to their higher ionic conductivity. However, inevitable introduction of CO2 would lead to the attenuation of OCV and out power density. To avoid this, SOFCs seem to be a surprising choice because of their isolation effects and elevated reaction rates under high operation temperature conditions although they do not utilize ammonia directly. Compared to SOFC-O, SOFC-H is more compatible due to the nature of oxygen ion conductor and the higher hydrogen partial pressure along with lower steam partial pressure in SOFC-H. Further studies are focused on low temperature DAFCs based on hydroxide exchange membranes because of their affinity to practical applications. Tremendous efforts have been implemented to make ammonia-based energy practical, nevertheless, we are still at the early stage. The existing problems, hampers and challenges mainly focus on the following aspects. (1) Mechanism is unclear yet. Although excellent experimental and theoretical calculation results provide a clear vision of the evolution of AOR, there are controversial parts in the process which demand the more direct and clear evidences. For instance, M-G mechanism suggests that N2Hy is responsible for the formation of N2, however, y would be different at different works. Obviously, although there are experimental errors, the greater possibility is that the mechanism is different, inspiring us that we should carry out more experiments and establish related relationship. What’s more, more details of reaction and the evolution of catalysts need the help of in situ methods like electron microscopy, X-Ray diffraction (XRD) and so on, thus the relationship between catalysts structure and performance could be better understood. (2) The performance of catalysts is limited. Practical applications and industrializations need catalysts to be both cheap and efficient. The extremely low current denisty of ammonia conversion may originate from the sluggish dynamics. Specifically, although precious metals show the appropriate adsorption energy for AOR intermediates, extremely strong N adsorption energy makes precious metals easy to be poisoned and further deactivation. For transition metals, the relative high energy barrier of NH x coupling leads to the electrochemical inertness at low overpotential. At present, the most common AOR catalysts are based on Pt-based and Ni-based materials, displaying the limitations of current researches. Thus, reducing the N poisoning effect on the surface of noble metals and NH x coupling barrier on the surface of transition metals are the keys to develop efficient catalysts. Compared to hydrogen and carbon-based fuel, lower peak current density of half-cell reaction and peak power density along with OCV of DAFCs push us to seek more satisfying options. On the one hand, the pursuit of non-precious metal based or even metal-free based materials for efficient AOR still needs further development. On the other hand, the modification of Pt-based catalysts needs to move forward a single step to decrease the loading of Pt, such as alloying with other elements, defect engineering, interface engineering and topography control. Also, the activity represented by Ni and some carbon materials should be considered as the most potential candidates. (3) Alkaline electrolyte membranes still cannot meet the requirements. As the key parts of low temperature DAFCs, the alkaline electrolyte membranes have received much attention and gained great progress nowadays, but their stability in alkaline environment at intermediate temperature (>80 °C) is still challenges. Based on the developed HEM, different polymer backbones and functional groups can be tried, such as polyetherketone, polyimide and polyvinylidene fluoride with imidazole, pyridine, guanidino and quaternary phosphorus group. At the same time, another serious problem is that ammonia crossover will cause cell performance degradation. Anyway, combined high stability and sufficient ionic conductivity is the guideline for the evolution of HEM. (4) DAFCs received less attention relative to hydrogen-based fuel cell. Although researches on DAFCs were initiated at early time, unfortunately, lack of basic researches, inadequate attentions to ammonia-based energy, and unsatisfactory devices hampered their thriving. Apart from the aspects mentioned above, to promote the flourish of DAFCs, additional factors are also required. At present, ammonia production cost is higher than that of hydrogen due to its requirement on additional process of ammonia production, prompting the search for new methods for ammonia production and further development of novel strategies such as photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. Additionally, the ammonia corrosion problem of the cell device itself is also needed to be concerned. coredata.dc:description: Green and sustainable options are needed to ease the current energy and environmental crisis, and alleviate the greenhouse effect and energy shortage. As an alternative carbon–neutral synthetic fuel, ammonia shows great potential due to its high energy density, non-toxic by-products, and mature related infrastructures. However, related practical applications have been severely hampered on ammonia-oxidation due to the high cost of catalysts and immature energy utilization systems. Here, we comprehensively summarized the efforts which have been made in recent years with the aim of providing a deep sight into the development and deficiencies in this territory and trying to establish a simple framework of basic knowledge for researchers. The exploration of mechanism is discussed first and then the relevant catalysts studied in recent years are summarized. Besides, the progress of direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs) is also presented and the challenges as well as perspectives on future developments of electrocatalysts for ammonia electro-oxidation and its practical application are provided at the end.

coredata.dc:title: An option for green and sustainable future: Electrochemical conversion of ammonia into nitrogen
